title: Hutchies builds more, profits less as costs bite
text:
Hutchies has also reduced its contract assets by $4.4 million for work it had completed for Ralan, but not yet billed, as of the same date.

However the Ralan exposure would not have a material impact on future financial years, according to a note to the accounts from Hutchies directors, who apart from chairman Scott Hutchinson, include his 85-year-old father, John Hutchinson.

Ralan's bad debt is arguably barely material in financial 2019, as Hutchies reported $156.4 million of contract assets, up from $81.3 million the prior year, based on $7.29 billion of project expenditure including profit recognised to date, less $7.13 billion in progress billings.

Projects Hutchies is currently building include Chinese conglomerate New Hope Group's 43-storey residential tower, The Landmark, at St Leonards on Sydney's lower north shore, and an $11 million facelift to the Beenleigh Magistrates Court south of Brisbane.

Wholly-owned by the Hutchinson family for 112 years, Hutchies has no external investor pressure to always maximise profits, a freedom it used in 2018-19 to complete live music venue Fortitude Music Hall.

A 3000-capacity replacement for Brisbane's storied Festival Hall, which was demolished for apartments in 2003, Fortitude Music Hall has a carrying value of $30 million despite Hutchies investing $45 million into the purpose-built venue.

"I had to buy this land [for $23 million last year] with a development application for 350 units so I had to pay that cost and then put a music venue on it," Scott Hutchinson told The Australian Financial Review in July, on the eve of its opening.

"We may borrow against it. The banks have a bit of trouble understanding it. It's an inter-generational investment."

Advertisement

The company remains well capitalised, with a cash pile of $387 million and net assets of $327 million.

A fully franked dividend of $232,047 was recommended for payment by the directors, down slightly on the $242,330 paid for 2017-18.

The builder has 1793 employees, up from 1637 the previous year, and was ranked Australia's sixth largest private company on 2019's Financial Review Top 500 Private Companies list.

Scott Hutchinson was in a dive boat off Cairns and unavailable for comment on Monday.
description: The builder owned by Queensland's Rich List Hutchinson family has received more than $3 billion from customers for the first time - but Ralan hasn't paid up.
